title: Carl Hoddle
text:
Carl Hoddle (8 March 1967 – 2 March 2008) was an English <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and <a href="coach%20%28sports%29">coach</a>.
The younger brother of <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> international <a href="Glenn%20Hoddle">Glenn Hoddle</a>, Carl began his career with <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a> in 1984. After two years he moved to <a href="Barnet%20F.C.">Barnet</a>, where he stayed until 1988 before moving to Bishop's Stortford in a swap deal for former Barnet player Ian Fergusson. After one season he was signed by <a href="Leyton%20Orient%20F.C.">Leyton Orient</a>, where he played 29 times, before returning to <a href="Barnet%20F.C.">Barnet</a> in 1991, ending his senior career in 1995 after 100 appearances. He also had a spell with <a href="Conference%20National">Conference National</a> side <a href="Woking%20F.C.">Woking</a>. 
One notable game he played for Barnet was in the FA Cup against <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> in 1994, who were at the time managed by his older brother. He later worked in the <a href="used%20car">used car</a> trade and as a <a href="pub">pub</a> <a href="landlord">landlord</a> before joining his older brother as a coach and scout at <a href="Wolverhampton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Wolverhampton Wanderers</a> between 2004 and 2006. He died on 2 March 2008 after he was found collapsed in his home from what was initially suspected to be a <a href="heart%20attack">heart attack</a> but later confirmed as a brain <a href="aneurysm">aneurysm</a>.
